context: The most precise timekeeping device of the ancient world was <a0_0><b5_0><b10_0>the water clock<b5_0/>, or <b7_0>clepsydra<b10_0/><b7_0/><a0_0/>, one of which was found in the tomb of <a1_0><b11_0>Egyptian pharaoh Amenhotep<b11_0/><a1_0/> I (1525–1504 BC). They could be used to measure the hours even at night, but required manual upkeep to replenish the flow of water. The Ancient Greeks and the people from Chaldea (southeastern Mesopotamia) regularly maintained timekeeping records <b8_0>as an essential part of their astronomical observations<b8_0/>. <a2_0><b12_0>Arab inventors<b12_0/><a2_0/> and engineers in particular made improvements on the use of water clocks <b9_0>up to the Middle Ages<b9_0/>. In <a4_0><b14_0>the 11th century<b14_0/><a4_0/>, <a3_0><b13_0>Chinese<b13_0/><a3_0/> inventors and engineers invented the first mechanical clocks driven by an <b6_0>escapement mechanism<b6_0/>.
